metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of flux observation matrix (No.8 eddy covariance system) of the MUlti-Scale Observation EXperiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (2012)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from site No.8 eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 28 May to 21 September, 2012. The site (100.37649° E, 38.87254° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Yingke irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1550.06 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.2 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500) was 0.15 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how eddy covariance systems are used to measure evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Example.Answer: The eddy covariance system was used in the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research to measure turbulent fluxes and evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, specifically in an irrigated agricultural area. This system collected data with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz, which was part of the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when estimating evapotranspiration using remote sensing data in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge in estimating evapotranspiration using remote sensing data in arid regions includes errors in derived component temperatures due to image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. This can result in overestimation of canopy temperature and complicate the accuracy of the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model used in such estimations.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a multiscale observation dataset used to study eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Example.Answer: The HiWATER experiment provides a multiscale dataset from the Heihe Watershed, which includes data from eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing using LiDAR and imaging spectrometers. This dataset captures eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems and is available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Definition.Question: What is the 'eddy covariance system' in the context of eco-hydrological observations?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance (EC) system is a data collection method used to measure turbulent fluxes of heat, water vapor, and carbon dioxide by capturing high-frequency data on wind speed and scalar concentrations, typically at a sampling frequency of 10 Hz. This method provides insights into the exchange processes between the land surface and the atmosphere, often used in heterogeneous landscapes such as those with mixed soil and vegetation.

Definition.Question: How is 'two-source energy balance (TSEB) model' used to estimate evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Definition.Answer: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model estimates evaporation, transpiration, and overall evapotranspiration by partitioning energy between the 'above canopy' and 'under soil' layers. It requires surface energy balance modeling with land surface temperature measurements to improve estimations of soil and canopy net radiation, aerodynamic resistance, and component temperatures, making it suitable for diverse vegetation types and spatial scales.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when collecting data from hierarchical observation networks versus single-location eddy covariance systems in heterogeneous landscapes?
Comparison.Answer: Hierarchical observation networks face challenges like ensuring data consistency across varied scales and environments, whereas single-location eddy covariance systems may struggle with energy balance closure and accurately capturing surface heterogeneity. The former requires integration of multi-disciplinary data, while the latter focuses on precise local measurements and data quality control.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to available energy. The uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences, errors in determining soil and vegetation component temperatures, and a strong advective environment are significant contributing factors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the overestimation of canopy temperature in arid regions when using composite temperature separation approaches?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The overestimation of canopy temperature in arid regions using composite temperature separation approaches is primarily caused by image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance. Soil pixels being counted as vegetation pixels due to classification errors, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation, and uncertainties in estimated incoming radiation transmittance contribute to this overestimation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of using high-resolution thermal imaging to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures in agricultural regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-resolution thermal imaging for estimating soil and canopy component temperatures can lead to improved separation and accuracy in calculating latent heat fluxes of soil and vegetation. This method enhances the validation of evapotranspiration estimates by providing detailed temperature data, which is critical for addressing the uncertainties in energy balance models and improving predictions of water fluxes in agricultural landscapes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of creating a multiscale dataset for observing eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of creating a multiscale dataset is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, which is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. The HiWATER experiment was designed to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration using stable isotopes and eddy covariance measurements in irrigation areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to validate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration using stable isotopes and eddy covariance measurements to achieve better accuracy in estimating these processes. This validation helps in addressing the challenges posed by strong advective conditions and incomplete energy balance closure in irrigation areas, ultimately improving the performance of models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of implementing a flux observation matrix using eddy covariance towers and other sensors in the context of the HiWATER project?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of implementing a flux observation matrix using eddy covariance towers and other sensors is to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area. This system is part of the HiWATER project and aims to provide comprehensive data on soil moisture, leaf area index, and other relevant parameters, facilitating a better understanding of the interaction between different landscapes and enhancing eco-hydrological research.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps for processing eddy covariance flux data to ensure accuracy and quality before analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps for processing eddy covariance flux data include using Edire software for post-processing the raw 10Hz data into 30-minute averages. The main steps involve despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, sonic temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Quality evaluation of flux values is also conducted, focusing on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Data is screened by removing erroneous data, data within one hour of precipitation, data with more than 3% missing in each 30-minute interval, and data during weak turbulence at night (u* less than 0.1 m/s).

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining accurate predictions of soil and canopy component temperatures using remote sensing technology in heterogeneous landscapes?
Expectation.Answer: Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors, which varied with vegetation abundance. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could result in uncertainties in estimated temperatures. This complexity highlights the difficulty in obtaining accurate soil and canopy component temperatures using remote sensing technology in heterogeneous landscapes.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated difficulties in using eddy covariance systems for measuring surface fluxes in irrigated agricultural areas?
Expectation.Answer: One anticipated difficulty is the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0, which is particularly challenging in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas. Higher uncertainty in H estimation, due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, can also pose challenges, especially when the mean H is small in irrigated farmland.

Expectation.Question: Why might multiscale observations be crucial for understanding eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Multiscale observations are crucial because they capture the complex eco-hydrological processes across different landscapes, such as sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. This comprehensive approach allows for a better understanding of the oasis-desert interaction, which is often hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using eddy covariance systems for measuring surface fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The eddy covariance (EC) system is widely used for measuring surface fluxes, such as latent and sensible heat fluxes, over heterogeneous landscapes. It is particularly useful in capturing the complexity of flux exchanges between the land surface and atmosphere. However, in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, it can be challenging due to incomplete energy balance closure and uncertainties in the derived component temperatures, especially when dealing with heterogeneous surfaces with mixed soil and vegetation. The effectiveness of EC systems can be enhanced by integrating high-resolution thermal camera data and stable isotopes for improved validation.

Judgmental.Question: What are some potential challenges in obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological research in oasis-desert environments?
Judgmental.Answer: Obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological research in oasis-desert environments poses several challenges. Progress is often hindered by the poor availability of comprehensive datasets that capture the diverse processes at play. The heterogeneity of the landscape, with its mixture of vegetation and soil types, complicates data collection. Additionally, arranging instruments on hierarchically nested scales to capture these processes effectively requires significant resources and planning. The need for continuous hydrometeorological observations, alongside intensive observation periods, adds further complexity to the data collection efforts.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and describe the primary data collection methods used for capturing evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes, and discuss the challenges associated with these methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: The primary data collection methods for capturing evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes include the use of eddy covariance systems, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. These methods are complemented by remote sensing tools such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and multi-angle thermal imagers. Challenges associated with these methods include the incomplete energy balance closure in eddy covariance measurements, the complexity of separating soil and canopy temperatures, and the need for multiscale observations to accurately capture eco-hydrological processes. Errors in component temperature classification and the limited effectiveness of temperature separation approaches in arid regions also pose significant challenges.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the process of quality control and data processing applied to datasets in eco-hydrological research, highlighting any specific techniques or software used.
Request/Directive.Answer: Quality control and data processing in eco-hydrological research involve several steps, including sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and generation of datasets. Specific techniques used include the Edire software for processing eddy covariance data, which involves steps like outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and various density corrections. Data quality is evaluated based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics, and only data meeting certain quality criteria are retained. The processed data are stored in standardized formats and are made available through platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss potential strategies for expanding and refining datasets related to evapotranspiration over heterogeneous surfaces, considering both ground-based and remote sensing technologies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Expanding and refining datasets related to evapotranspiration over heterogeneous surfaces can be achieved by integrating ground-based observations with advanced remote sensing technologies. Strategies include increasing the density and coverage of eddy covariance towers and meteorological stations to capture diverse landscape conditions, and enhancing the spatial and temporal resolution of airborne remote sensing missions using LiDAR, thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers. Additionally, employing high-resolution thermal cameras for accurate component temperature measurements and using stable isotope techniques for validating evapotranspiration estimates can further refine datasets. Collaborative efforts to share data through open-access platforms and the development of robust data assimilation models can also contribute to dataset enhancement.
